hints.content:
We can start with a fraction and change the way we divide the whole to make an **equivalent fraction.**

Equivalent fractions have the same area as each other.

This square has $\blueE{4}$ equal parts, with $\maroonD{2}$ parts shaded. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{2}}{\blueE{4}}$.

 ![fraction with 2 of 4 equal parts shaded](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5090f857ae5bf397414fe38435bdd37e79d70000)

We can split up the whole square in a different way but keep the same area.

 ![fraction with the same area with 1 of 2 equal parts shaded](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/20bb9d1b97b2c3741e0c576bda4f3cebdfe46a55)

This square has $\blueE{p}$ equal parts, with $\maroonD{1}$ part shaded. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{1}}{\blueE{p}}$.

How many equal parts are in the square?
There are $\blueE{2}$ equal parts per square, so $\blueE{p}=\blueE{2}$.
